node.text: Great design chat with the multi hyphenate design duo Jessie and Mara Carrier of Carrier and Co., - Joy Of Design Live for Veranda Magazine!

node.title: Carrier and Co., with Joy Moyler

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Manhattan, New York. May be an image of furniture and living room.

node.text:
As summer begins to wind down, we're dreaming of crisp fall days and cozy nights, many of them spent reading by the fire. Thankfully, the upcoming season is ripe for a slew of new design books, many of them making our favorite designers first-time authors. Tap the link in bio to learn about 23 new books that celebrate the joys of design.

Pictured is Charlotte Moss's (@charmossny) New York library which is covered in a rich gauffrage serge antique fabric (@claremontus). 
–
 Photography by Miguel Flores-Vianna, from the VER archive.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in West Village. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Candy pink walls maybe a little too much for some people. But for author and antiques dealer Emily Eerdmans (@eerdmansnewyork), they serve as a vivacious backdrop for an ever-changing inventory of antiques and art. The lower salon of her West Village gallery-in-residence acts as a vivid shop with wall-to-wall leopard print carpet (a nod to Madeleine Castaing) that hides disparate surfaces below. The painting is 'Butterflies' by Hunt Slonem (@huntslonem). The pink wall paint color is Nancy’s Blushes by Farrow & Ball (@farrowandball).

Want to see more of this wildly immersive gallery-in-residence? Tap the link in bio!
—
Photography by Kelly Marshall (@sans.murs)
Produced by Dayle Wood (@daylewood24)
Written by Michael Diaz-Griffith (@michaeldiazgriffith)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Veranda Magazine on September 03, 2021 tagging @counterpointpress. May be an image of text that says 'VERANDA BOOK CLUB SEPTEMBER 2021 Woven World On Fashion, Fishermen, and the SardineDress Sardine ALISON HAWTHORYE DEMING'.

node.text:
Need a new book to read this month? Look no further! Our September pick for the VERANDA Sip and Read Club is Alison Hawthorne Deming's 'A Woven World," an interconnected story of fashion, fishermen, and preservation. 

This month, we will be hosting an Instagram live with Deming on Sept. 28 at 12 p.m. EST.  To learn more about the selection, tap the link in bio! Happy reading!

#versipandreadclub

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
In restoring this 1840s London rowhouse, designer Gary McBournie (@garymcbournie) and architect Mike Fisher of Studio Indigo (@studioindigoltd) set out to honor the home's original Victorian architecture and spirit. Fischer's colleague James Kandutsch had casts made from fragments of original details uncovered during demolition so they could be replicated exactly and found floor plans detailing each stage of the house’s expansions and renovations. Where there was no historic record, he adapted features of similar buildings from the period. An example of this is the curved staircase topped by an oval oculus that pours daylight into the house’s core. “Our philosophy was, let’s restore the building in the most authentic way possible,” says Fisher. “And that created this wonderful canvas for Gary to add his layer of wonder.”

Inspired by the historic era's color palette, McBournie paired an elegant powder blue shade with snowy white trim in the entry. A geometric arrangement of jewel tones ascends the stairs (@starkcarpet). 

Tap the link in bio to see more of this storybook rowhouse in London.
—
Landscape design by Iain MacDonald Design (@iainmacdonald.design)
Photography by Dylan Thomas (@dylan_location)
Written by Celia Barbour

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine on September 01, 2021. May be an image of tree, outdoors and text that says 'CALL FOR ENTRIES! VERANDA Best of OUTDOOR LIVING 2022 Our 3RD ANNUAL AWARDS Recognizing Excellence in Landscape Design (NOW, WITH NEW CATEGORIES!)'.

node.text:
DEADLINE EXTENDED! Enter by Friday, September 10! Submit your best gardens, greenhouses, pools, pool houses, porches, loggias, courtyards, dining terraces, & more! PLUS, NEW THIS YEAR: Nominate landscape visionaries in the categories of botanical innovation, original approach to design, wellness, preservation, and lifetime achievement.

Judges Bunny Williams and Institute of Classical Architecture & Art president Peter Lyden, along with Veranda editors, will choose the winners, announced in our March/April 2022 issue.

Tap the link in bio to learn how to enter, and tag someone who should enter!
-
Garden design by Scott Shrader (@scott_shrader)
Photography by Lisa Romerein (@lisaromerein)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Manhattan, New York. May be art of furniture and indoor.

node.text:
When it came to decorating this historic apartment overlooking Madison Square Park, comfortability and functionality were key factors for designer Robert Passal (@robertpassal). “The apartment wasn’t meant to be splashy,” explains the designer. “We had a distinct look we were going for, which was calm and clean.”

For the entryway, the designer brought in artisans to embellish the walls with fluted plaster, making a subtle yet high-impact statement. The plasterwork serves as a backdrop for a distinct piece of art called "Sunbathers" by Hayley Mitchell (@hayley_km). The chandelier is by Visual Comfort (@visualcomfort).

Tap the link in bio to see more of this polished three-bedroom apartment in New York.
—
Photography by Stephen Kent Johnson (@stephenkentjohnson)
Written by Stephen Wallis (@stephen_wallis)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine on August 30, 2021. May be an image of rose and prairie gentian.

node.text:
The perfect Monday pick-me-up. ✨

— 
📸: @gulshanlondon
💐: Wild Things Flowers (@wildthingsflowers)
#regram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine on August 30, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Painstakingly foraged, deconstructed, dried, reconstructed, and mounted, a pressed botanical demands a naturalist’s precision and an artist’s hand. That dualism fits Anne Blackwell Thompson (@blackwell_botanicals) like a pair of waders. Her latest obsession: water lilies, which require changing blotting paper every six hours, day and night, for up to 10 days. Here, Thompson captures the artistic beauty of water lilies in a botanical piece exclusively for Veranda.

Tap the link in bio to learn more about the piece and how you can enter for a chance to win the artwork.
—
Photography by Becky Stayner (@sunnyhousestudio)
Produced by Sara Clark (@saraellisclark)
Written by Tracey Minkin (@tracey_minkin)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in West Village. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Walking into the upper salon of Emily Eerdmans's West Village gallery-in-residence feels akin to taking a shot of pure caffeine. Both light-filled and lime-lacquered, the immersive space serves as a vivid shop gallery for an ever-changing inventory of antiques and art. Eerdmans (@eerdmansnewyork) softened the salon's electric appearance with gentle details such as tasseled Austrian shades (@samuelandsons), a portiere hiding the kitchen, and monumental Christmas palms. 

Want to see more of this wildly immersive gallery-in-residence? Tap the link in bio!
—
Photography by Kelly Marshall (@sans.murs)
Produced by Dayle Wood (@daylewood24)
Written by Michael Diaz-Griffith (@michaeldiazgriffith)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Positano. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Oh, Italy. You've always been a beauty. ✨
—
📸: @bmseventh
📍: Positano, Italy
#regram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Montreal, Quebec. May be an image of chandelier, table and indoor.

node.text:
Designer Richard Ouellette and architect Maxime Vandal, the team behind Les Ensembliers (@les_ensembliers), recasted a dilapidated chapel as an art-filled penthouse for former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his wife, Mila in Montreal. When it came to devising the layout for the 6,000 square feet of living space—plus another 2,000 square feet of rooftop terrace—the challenge, Vandal says, “was to translate the Mulroneys’ life in their previous home to the more contained volume of the apartment without any compromise.”

The goal was to create a residence that is comfortable when it’s just the two of them, while also allowing the couple to host family gatherings and entertain on the generous scale they are accustomed to.

The main entertaining space is divided into three sections including this corner dining area. The majestic antique crystal chandelier anchors the room. A shagreen leather (@garrettleather) covers custom chairs. The painting is by Larry Poons.

To see more of this art-filled penthouse, tap the link in bio.
—
Photography by Thomas Loof (@thomasloof)
Produced by Dayle Wood (@daylewood24)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Knightsbridge. May be an image of furniture and living room.

node.text:
It was like a scene out of a movie. One day while exploring the quiet London neighborhood of Knightsbridge, an American couple stumbled across a four-story, white stucco rowhouse dripping with charm. The couple couldn't pass up the chance, and not soon after, the home was theirs. 

While stunning from the outside, Boston-based designer Gary McBournie (@garymcbournie) and London-based architect Mike Fisher will tell you that the cinematic appeal disappeared once inside. 

"At one point, you could stand on bare earth, look up through four floors, and see sky,” explains Fisher of Studio Indigo (@studioindigoltd).

The teams looked to historic documents for inspiration to emulate the home's original Victorian elements. However, most of the palette and patterns for the house, for example, came from a single small antique Turkish rug which McBournie had recreated as a large living room rug.  The convivial window seat In the living room overlooks an emerald and white back garden. The striped banquette fabric is by Pierre Frey. The French lantern was found at Carlton Davidson Antiques. 

Tap the link in bio to see more of this storybook rowhouse in London. 
—
Landscape design by Iain MacDonald Design (@iainmacdonald.design)

Written by Celia Barbour
